It‚Äôs 2020 yet I‚Äôm baffled at why someone‚Äôs skin colour still makes a difference to how they‚Äôre treated. So many people are getting called out on here but I can understand that EVERYONE has their ways of dealing with things. Some people internalise, some people scream off the top of their lungs, some people punch things etc. I‚Äôve had a few conversations with my friends and family and it‚Äôs almost sad because am I surprised that this shit is still happening? No not really. Someone asked me how I feel about this situation and so many POC are going to absolutely hate me for saying this but in all honesty, I feel slightly relieved. 50/60/70 years ago, we didn‚Äôt have social media, or cameras on our phones. We didn‚Äôt have platforms where regular people could speak up. Where regular people like me and you can educate others and be listened to and taken seriously. The bottom of the line is, our world is still racist but I feel that the world is more awake than ever before. Back then, do you think something like this would get so much coverage? Absolutely not. I know where I came from - my last name is Thomas ffs and come on, that definitely wouldn‚Äôt have been my original surname. Am I worried to bring a child of colour into this world? Yes. But I recognise that slavery happened for 400+ years, and radical change takes a long time. It‚Äôs been such a short time being out of that. I hate that people have to suffer for change to happen, of course it breaks my heart! No one can tell me different! I will be making one about inclusive resource-sharing shortly, as well. // ORANGE BACKGROUND WITH WHITE AND LIGHT-COLORED TEXT. Title slide: disability-inclusive protest etiquette: a guide. Slide 2: Remember that many disabled people will not be able to attend protests, no matter how much they want to be there. Avoid language like ‚Äújust show up,‚Äù ‚Äúthe front lines are where the real work is done,‚Äù etc. It is ableist, shaming, and unhelpful. There are many ways to be involved, such as organizing, donating, and doing daily work. Doing the work is not unique to the front lines. Slide 3: some disabled people will be attending protests alongside you. Understand that you won‚Äôt always know who they are, as many disabilities are invisible. Respect people‚Äôs space. Do not touch physically disabled people or their wheelchairs/mobility equipment. Don‚Äôt tell anyone you‚Äôre inspired by them. And this is an absolute rule: never assume someone is ‚Äúfaking it‚Äù if you see them using a mobility device one minute and not the next. Slide 4: contact protestors beforehand to ensure that events are accessible. Specific actions include: ensuring there is a rally alternative to each march, checking in about access to ramps/restrooms and interpreters, providing mobility aids and a team to assist if possible, ensuring that all organized protest language is anti-ableist. Slide 5: educate yourself - black disabled people should never be an afterthought, especially when it comes to police brutality. Disabled people make up between one third and one half of all people killed by police. This issue is CENTRAL to the black disabled community. Learn the names of black disabled victims of police violence. Advocate for measures that protect disabled people whenever you discuss deescalation techniques or alternatives to police.
